awd_titl_txt: MRI: Acquisition of a Quadrupole ICP-MS for Multidisciplinary Research, Research Training, and Education at Colgate University
awd_abstract_narration:
This award provides funding to Colgate University Geology Department for a new geochemical analysis instrument. The new instrument, called an Inductively Coupled Mass Spectrometer or ICP-MS, measures chemical elements in various materials. The facility will support research and research training in the physical and social sciences at Colgate University, as well as at numerous research programs at predominantly undergraduate colleges in the upstate New York region and beyond. Projects include studies of the composition of Earth's interior, formation of volcanic island chains, ice movement in the Antarctic, the formation of the Adirondack Mountains, volcanic lakes, airborne contaminants, Roman archaeological sites, the role of climate change in early human evolution, roadside spring water quality and surface runoff in the Finger Lakes Region, and identification of Paleolithic art pigments. The new instrument extends the two-decade history of the ICP-MS facility at Colgate University. More than 10 faculty and 50-80 student investigators will use the instrument during the grant period. Users will share their research with the public and the scientific community, testament to the wide reach of this interdisciplinary analytical facility. The ICP-MS will also be a cornerstone facility for courses at Colgate and nearby institutions, providing hands-on experience with modern instrumentation for many undergraduates.

The new quadrupole Inductively Coupled Plasma-Mass Spectrometer (ICP-MS) in the Colgate University Geology Department will support research and research training in the physical and social sciences across our institution, as well as in numerous research programs at predominantly undergraduate colleges in the upstate New York region and beyond. Projects include investigations into mantle compositions and ocean island geodynamics, magmatic evolution, provenance of Antarctic phonolites and their implications for ice sheet movement, petrochronology of Adirondack rocks, banded iron formation analog processes, volcanic lakes and hydrothermal systems, silt emplacement in the Dry Valleys of Antarctica, formation of glaciovolcanic ridges, characterization of airborne particulates, tephrochronology in cores from the Temple of Athena at Paestum, roof tile terracotta provenance from Italian archaeological sites, paleoclimate variations and implications for early hominid evolution, multi-year studies of roadside spring water quality and surface runoff in the Finger Lakes Region, and geochemistry of Paleolithic art pigments. Users of the instrument will disseminate their research to the scientific community through publications, conference presentations, and public outreach, collaborate with scientists at major research institutions, and receive national funding for their projects, testament to the wide reach of this interdisciplinary analytical facility. The ICP-MS will also be a cornerstone facility for courses at Colgate and nearby institutions, providing hands-on experience with modern instrumentation for many undergraduates.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

por.por_cntn:
Intellectual Merit:
A new quadrupole inductively coupled plasma-mass spectrometer has been installed at Colgate University in the Earth and Environmental Geosciences Department. Current ongoing projects include: a) an investigation into the structure and composition of the Galapagos mantle plume through a study of the easternmost seamounts; and b) a study of the eruptive behavior of Augustine volcano 400-1000 years ago, to assess its explosiveness in the context of more recent historical eruptions. Five undergraduate students have been trained in use of the ICP-MS, including sample preparation, data acquisition, and data interpretation. As of this summer, two students will have presented first-authored presentations at national and international conferences with data generated in our new ICP-MS facility.

There were delays in setting up the instrument owing to the pandemic and post-pandemic recovery, but as of January 2025, we are fully functional and engaged in research projects that integrate undergraduate students, as described above. This summer (2025), we will be inviting the researchers listed in the proposal to begin using the facility at their convenience. These projects include studies of the provenance of Antarctic phonolites and their implications for ice movement, petrochronology of Adirondack rocks, banded iron formation analog processes, volcanic lakes and hydrothermal systems, silt emplacement processes in the Dry Valleys of Antarctica, formation processes of glaciovolcanic ridges, characterization of airborne particulates, tephrochronology in cores from the Temple of Athena at Paestum, roof tile terracotta provenance from Italian archaeological sites, paleoclimate variations and implications for early hominin evolution, multi-year studies of roadside spring water quality and surface runoff in the Finger Lakes Region, and an investigation into Paleolithic art pigments.  

Broader Impacts:
The new instrument continues the more than two-decade history of the ICP-MS facility at Colgate University. Data produced in this facility will contribute to research projects in a wide range of geoscience disciplines. Critically, undergraduate students working on these research projects and taking classes at Colgate gain training in geochemical research techniques, data management, and interpretation. Most of the students who became proficient on the previous ICP-MS have pursued graduate degrees in the geosciences or careers in science education, evidence for the positive impact of undergraduate research on the STEM field. The new ICP-MS is essential for courses at Colgate and nearby institutions, including geochemistry, environmental science, and instrumental analysis, and will be integrated into those over the next two years; our geochemistry course has already benefited from the facility. Several of these courses engage students in community-collaborative research projects, allowing students to develop their communication skills, and providing an important mechanism for science outreach.
